newsitem.title: GERMANY: German industrial orders grow for second month.
newsitem.headline: German industrial orders grow for second month.

text.p: German industrial orders rose in July for the second month in a row, picking up by 0.6 percent after a 1.9 percent gain in June, the economics ministry said Wednesday.
An increase of 0.9 percent in western Germany was partly offset by a 4.7 percent drop in the so-called "new states" of former communist eastern Germany.
Pan-German industrial orders were down by 0.1 percent in July against the same month a year earlier, after a two percent rise in June, according to calculations based on Bundesbank data.
Orders in the west were down by 1 percent year-on-year, while in the east they were still up by a rampant 21 percent.
The month-on-month orders number was just above a consensus forecast of plus 0.3 percent from economists polled by Reuters -- but within overall expectations.
Data across the board showed strong growth of over seven percent in foreign orders, while domestic orders were sluggish and slipped back by nearly three percent against June.
The orders figures follow industrial output figures issued on Tuesday that also showed a deceleration in month-on-month growth in July from June in a growth trend stretching back five months.
Gross domestic product figures for the second quarter are due to be published on Thursday and economists expect them to show a strong rebound after a weather-hit first quarter.
